free_text.Learning outcomes: This course serves as an introduction to the economics of information and its strategic ramifications. The main objectives are:[br/]o	to use economic theory to understand strategic interactions in the presence of uncertainty and estimate the value of information;[br/]o	to analyze competitive strategy in an information economy.[br/][br/]
free_text.Content: Readings and cases are used to discuss the following topics:[br/][br/]1.	Competition and Market Power[br/]2.	Product Differentiation[br/]3.	Pricing Methods[br/]4.	Externalities and System Effects[br/]5.	Moral Hazard and Incentives[br/]6.	Markets and Intermediaries[br/]7.	Imperfect Competition: Search Markets[br/]8.	Auctions and Bargaining[br/]9.	Prediction Markets[br/]10.	Special Topics
free_text.Bibliography and material: Reading bulkpack[br/][br/]McAfee, R.P. (2005) Competitive Solutions : The Strategist's Toolkit, Princeton University Press: Princeton, NJ.[br/][br/]Shapiro, C., Varian, H. (1999) Information Rules : A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy, Harvard Business School Press: Boston, MA.
free_text.Form of examination: 20% Homework[br/]40% Team project[br/]30% Written exam[br/]10% Class participation
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Principles of Microeconomics (MGT-454) or equivalent course
